# The Codeine Controversy

**From:** The New Yorker Weekly <newyorker@newsletter.newyorker.com>
**Date:** Mon, 26 Jan 2026 19:46:42 -0500 (EST)
**Source:** [View original](https://link.newyorker.com/view/5bea16dd3f92a40469736b16q1lyx.7ws2/20dd11db)

---

The New Yorker Weekly Newsletter

Ben Taub reports on the repercussions of a baby&#x2019;s mysterious death. Plus: reporting and analysis after another fatal shooting in Minneapolis.

[

](https://link.newyorker.com/view/5bea16dd3f92a40469736b16q1lyx.7ws2/20dd11db)

The New Yorker&#x2019;s award-winning journalism is made possible by our subscribers. [Become one today &#xBB;](https://link.newyorker.com/click/43745145.)

In today&#x2019;s edition: Ben Taub on the repercussions of a baby&#x2019;s mysterious death. Plus: reporting and analysis after another fatal shooting in Minneapolis; and what Democrats can learn from MAGA. [Jump to a complete list of what&#x2019;s in this week&#x2019;s issue](https://link.newyorker.com/click/43745145.).

David Remnick

Editor, The New Yorker

In 2005, a twelve-day-old baby named Tariq Jamieson died in Canada. The coroner found no anatomical cause of death&#x2014;no physical reason he should&#x2019;ve died. But a blood sample taken at his autopsy, and later tested, determined that the baby had died of codeine-and-morphine poisoning. Jamieson&#x2019;s mother had been prescribed Tylenol No. 3, which includes codeine, after a difficult childbirth. The body can metabolize some codeine into morphine.

Illustration by Juan Bernabeu

The coroner&#x2019;s office asked one of the country&#x2019;s leading pediatricians and toxicologists, Gideon Koren, to look at the case. Koren concluded that Jamieson had died after ingesting morphine through his mother&#x2019;s breast milk&#x2014;according to Koren, it was the first reported death-by-breast-milk case in history. He and a team of researchers later published a paper about the case in The Lancet, a prestigious international medical journal. It argued that, for some mothers with a certain genetic predisposition, taking even a mild dose of codeine could make their breast milk deadly.

American, Canadian, and European regulators all updated their guidance around codeine and breast-feeding. Doctors began prescribing other opioids to new moms&#x2014;stronger, more addictive ones. But, in the years that followed, other researchers began to suspect that the science in the Jamieson case was wrong&#x2014;and that Tariq had actually been given the medication directly.

In this week&#x2019;s issue, the staff writer Ben Taub carefully [considers the evidence, and talks to researchers about the case](https://link.newyorker.com/click/43745145.) and its far-reaching impact. &#x201C;The number of infants affected by this globally is now easily in the millions,&#x201D; one researcher told Taub. (The Jamiesons maintain that Tariq died from breast milk.) This is a sensitive story, with very real repercussions, deeply examined. It&#x2019;s a stunning work of reporting.

[Read the story](https://link.newyorker.com/click/43745145.)

In Case You Missed It

Dispatch
The Battle for Minneapolis

As Donald Trump brings his retribution to a liberal city, citizens, protesters, and civic leaders try to protect one another.

By Emily Witt

On Television
Witnessing Another Public Killing in Minneapolis

Videos of Alex Pretti&#x2019;s fatal shooting, rapidly disseminated on social media, reveal a brazen display of brute power.

By Vinson Cunningham

The Political Scene
The Mayor of an Occupied City

Jacob Frey, of Minneapolis, is governing a city under siege by its own federal government.

By Ruby Cramer

As Told To
A Massacre in Mashhad

Under the cover of an internet blackout, Iranian security forces killed hundreds of demonstrators. Only now are details of the carnage starting to emerge.

By Cora Engelbrecht

The New Yorker Interview
Gus Kenworthy Lived an Olympic Version of &#x201C;Heated Rivalry&#x201D;

Ahead of a comeback in Milan, the Olympic freestyle skier and actor discusses alley-oops, auditions, and coming out of the closet as a professional athlete.

By Eren Orbey

Our Columnists

Letter from Trump&#x2019;s Washington
It&#x2019;s Time to Talk About Donald Trump&#x2019;s Logorrhea

How many polite ways are there to ask whether the President of the United States is losing it?

By Susan B. Glasser

Fault Lines
Can American Churches Lead a Protest Movement Under Trump?

The Sanctuary Movement was led by clergy, and many religious leaders are activists today. But, as congregations have shrunk, dissent has diminished.

By Jay Caspian Kang

Quote of the Week

&#x201C;It&#x2019;s, like, obviously you say, &#x2018;Yes.&#x2019; And then they&#x2019;re, like, &#x2018;We&#x2019;re going to pay you to do it.&#x2019; And you&#x2019;re, like, That&#x2019;s so cool. Not only do I get to do it; they&#x2019;re going to pay me&#x2014;that&#x2019;s sick.&#x201D;

&#x2014; Alex Honnold on why he chose to climb one of the tallest buildings in the world without a rope
